title: Eta Piscis Austrini
text:
Eta Piscis Austrini (η Piscis Austrini) is <a href="binary%20star">binary star</a> system in the southern constellation of <a href="Piscis%20Austrinus">Piscis Austrinus</a>. As of 2000, the two components had an <a href="angular%20separation">angular separation</a> of 1.818 <a href="arc%20second">arc second</a>s along a <a href="position%20angle">position angle</a> of 113.4°. The pair have a combined <a href="apparent%20visual%20magnitude">apparent visual magnitude</a> of +5.43, which is bright enough to be seen with the naked eye. Based upon an annual <a href="parallax">parallax</a> shift of 3.99 <a href="milliarcsecond">mas</a> as seen from the Earth, the system is located roughly 820 <a href="light%20year">light year</a>s from the <a href="Sun">Sun</a>.
The magnitude 5.7 primary, component A, is a blue-white hued <a href="Be%20star">Be star</a> with a <a href="stellar%20classification">stellar classification</a> B8 V. At the age of 115, the star is spinning rapidly with a <a href="projected%20rotational%20velocity">projected rotational velocity</a> of 265. It has an estimated four times the <a href="mass%20of%20the%20Sun">mass of the Sun</a> and is radiating 604 times the <a href="solar%20luminosity">solar luminosity</a> at an <a href="effective%20temperature">effective temperature</a> of 11,272 K. The secondary, component B, has a visual magnitude of 6.8.
Eta Piscis Austrini is moving through the Galaxy at a speed of 11.3 km/s relative to the Sun. Its projected Galactic orbit carries it between 23,600 and 30,800 light years from the center of the Galaxy.
